Symptoms: Itchy skin., Fatigue., Confusion, drowsiness and slurred speech, called hepatic encephalopathy., Dark-colored urine., Bleeding easily., Weight loss.
Treatment: Access to HCV treatment is improving but remains limited. Of the 50 million people living with HCV infection globally in 2022, an estimated 36% people knew their diagnosis, and of those diagnosed with chronic HCV infection, around 20% (12.5 million) people had been treated with DAAs by the end of 2022.

Symptoms: Swelling in the legs., Fatigue., Yellowing of the skin, called jaundice. This might show up more in white people. Also, yellowing of the whites of the eyes in white, Black and brown people., Confusion, drowsiness and slurred speech, called hepatic encephalopathy., Bleeding easily., Weight loss.
Treatment: Pan-genotypic DAAs remain expensive in many high- and upper-middle-income countries. However, prices have dropped dramatically in many countries (primarily low-income and lower-middle-income countries) due to the introduction of generic versions of these medicines. The most widely used and low-cost pangenotypic DAA regimen is sofosbuvir and daclatasvir. In many low- and middle-income countries the curative treatment course is available for less than US$ 50.

Also, yellowing of the whites of the eyes in white, Black and brown people., Confusion, drowsiness and slurred speech, called hepatic encephalopathy., Bleeding easily., Not wanting to eat.
Treatment: There are effective treatments for hepatitis C. The goal of treatment is to cure the disease and prevent long-term liver damage.

Treatment: There is no specific antiviral treatment for hepatitis A. Instead, the management of hepatitis A focuses on supportive care to relieve symptoms and ensure adequate hydration and nutrition. Symptoms: Fluid buildup in the stomach area, called ascites., Swelling in the legs., Spiderlike blood vessels on the skin, called spider angiomas., Yellowing of the skin, called jaundice. This might show up more in white people. Also, yellowing of the whites of the eyes in white, Black and brown people., Confusion, drowsiness and slurred speech, called hepatic encephalopathy., Dark-colored urine., Bleeding easily., Not wanting to eat.
Treatment: Acute HCV infections are usually asymptomatic and most do not lead to a life-threatening disease. Around 30% (15–45%) of infected persons spontaneously clear the virus within 6 months of infection without any treatment.

Symptoms: Unusual tiredness and weakness, Clay- or gray-colored stool, Sudden nausea and vomiting and diarrhea, Abdominal pain or discomfort, especially on the upper right side beneath your lower ribs, which is over your liver, Dark urine
Treatment: There is no specific antiviral treatment for hepatitis A. Instead, the management of hepatitis A focuses on supportive care to relieve symptoms and ensure adequate hydration and nutrition. Recovery from symptoms following infection may be slow and can take several weeks or months. It is important to avoid unnecessary medications that can adversely affect the liver, e.g. acetaminophen, paracetamol.

Symptoms: Fluid buildup in the stomach area, called ascites., Spiderlike blood vessels on the skin, called spider angiomas., Confusion, drowsiness and slurred speech, called hepatic encephalopathy., Dark-colored urine., Bleeding easily., Weight loss.
Treatment:
WHO organizes annual World Hepatitis Day campaigns to increase awareness and understanding of viral
    hepatitis. For World Hepatitis Day 2023, WHO focuses on the theme “One life,
    one liver” to illustrate the importance of the liver for a healthy life and the
    need to scale up viral hepatitis prevention, testing and treatment to prevent
    liver diseases and achieve the 2030 hepatitis elimination target.

Symptoms: Fluid buildup in the stomach area, called ascites., Swelling in the legs., Itchy skin., Fatigue., Yellowing of the skin, called jaundice. This might show up more in white people. Also, yellowing of the whites of the eyes in white, Black and brown people., Confusion, drowsiness and slurred speech, called hepatic encephalopathy., Bleeding easily., Not wanting to eat., Weight loss.
Treatment: Access to HCV treatment is improving but remains limited. Of the 50 million people living with HCV infection globally in 2022, an estimated 36% people knew their diagnosis, and of those diagnosed with chronic HCV infection, around 20% (12.5 million) people had been treated with DAAs by the end of 2022.

Symptoms: Spiderlike blood vessels on the skin, called spider angiomas., Fatigue., Confusion, drowsiness and slurred speech, called hepatic encephalopathy., Bleeding easily., Not wanting to eat., Weight loss.
Treatment: There are effective treatments for hepatitis C. The goal of treatment is to cure the disease and prevent long-term liver damage.

Symptoms: Yellowing of the skin and the whites of your eyes (jaundice), Clay- or gray-colored stool, Low-grade fever, Sudden nausea and vomiting and diarrhea, Abdominal pain or discomfort, especially on the upper right side beneath your lower ribs, which is over your liver, Intense itching
Treatment: Hospitalization is unnecessary in the absence of severe disease or acute liver failure. Therapy is aimed at maintaining comfort and adequate nutritional balance, including replacement of fluids that are lost from vomiting and diarrhoea.

Symptoms: Swelling in the legs., Itchy skin., Bleeding easily., Weight loss.
Treatment: Acute HCV infections are usually asymptomatic and most do not lead to a life-threatening disease. Around 30% (15–45%) of infected persons spontaneously clear the virus within 6 months of infection without any treatment.

Symptoms: Fluid buildup in the stomach area, called ascites., Swelling in the legs., Bruising easily., Itchy skin., Confusion, drowsiness and slurred speech, called hepatic encephalopathy., Bleeding easily., Not wanting to eat., Weight loss.
Treatment: WHO recommends therapy with pan-genotypic direct-acting antivirals (DAAs) for all adults, adolescents and children down to 3 years of age with chronic hepatitis C infection. The short-course oral, curative DAA treatment regimens has few if any side-effects. DAAs can cure most persons with HCV infection, and treatment duration is short (usually 12 to 24 weeks), depending on the absence or presence of cirrhosis. In 2022, WHO included new recommendations for treatment of adolescents and children using the same pangenotypic treatments used for adults.

Symptoms: Fluid buildup in the stomach area, called ascites., Fatigue., Yellowing of the skin, called jaundice. This might show up more in white people. Also, yellowing of the whites of the eyes in white, Black and brown people., Confusion, drowsiness and slurred speech, called hepatic encephalopathy., Dark-colored urine., Bleeding easily., Not wanting to eat., Weight loss.
Treatment: Acute HCV infections are usually asymptomatic and most do not lead to a life-threatening disease. Around 30% (15–45%) of infected persons spontaneously clear the virus within 6 months of infection without any treatment.

Symptoms: Fluid buildup in the stomach area, called ascites., Swelling in the legs., Spiderlike blood vessels on the skin, called spider angiomas., Yellowing of the skin, called jaundice. Also, yellowing of the whites of the eyes in white, Black and brown people., Confusion, drowsiness and slurred speech, called hepatic encephalopathy., Dark-colored urine., Bleeding easily., Not wanting to eat., Weight loss.
Treatment: People with hepatitis C may also benefit from lifestyle changes, such as avoiding alcohol and maintaining a healthy weight. With proper treatment, many people can be cured from hepatitis C infection and live healthy lives.

Symptoms: Unusual tiredness and weakness, Yellowing of the skin and the whites of your eyes (jaundice), Dark urine
Treatment: The GHSS recommend shared and disease-specific country actions supported by actions by WHO and partners. They consider the epidemiological, technological, and contextual shifts of previous years, foster learnings across the disease areas, and create opportunities to leverage innovations and new knowledge for effective responses to the diseases. They call to scale up prevention, testing and treatment of viral hepatitis with a focus to reach populations and communities most affected and at risk for each disease, as well as addressing gaps and inequities. They promote synergies under a universal health coverage and primary health care framework and contribute to achieving the goals of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development.

Treatment: WHO organizes annual World Hepatitis Day campaigns (as 1 of its 9 flagship annual health campaigns) to increase awareness and understanding of viral hepatitis. For World Hepatitis Day 2024, WHO focuses on the theme “It’s time for action” to illustrate the urgency of scaling up viral hepatitis prevention, testing and treatment to prevent liver diseases and cancer and achieve the 2030 hepatitis elimination target.

Symptoms: Fluid buildup in the stomach area, called ascites., Swelling in the legs., Spiderlike blood vessels on the skin, called spider angiomas., Fatigue., Confusion, drowsiness and slurred speech, called hepatic encephalopathy., Dark-colored urine., Bleeding easily., Not wanting to eat., Weight loss.
Treatment: After a person has been diagnosed with chronic HCV infection, an assessment should be conducted to determine the degree of liver damage (fibrosis and cirrhosis). This can be done by liver biopsy or through a variety of non-invasive tests. The degree of liver damage is used to guide treatment decisions and management of the disease.

Symptoms: Swelling in the legs., Spiderlike blood vessels on the skin, called spider angiomas., Yellowing of the skin, called jaundice. This might show up more in white people. Also, yellowing of the whites of the eyes in white, Black and brown people., Dark-colored urine., Bleeding easily., Not wanting to eat.
Treatment: Pan-genotypic DAAs remain expensive in many high- and upper-middle-income countries. However, prices have dropped dramatically in many countries (primarily low-income and lower-middle-income countries) due to the introduction of generic versions of these medicines. The most widely used and low-cost pangenotypic DAA regimen is sofosbuvir and daclatasvir. In many low- and middle-income countries the curative treatment course is available for less than US$ 50.

Treatment: There are effective treatments for hepatitis C. The goal of treatment is to cure the disease and prevent long-term liver damage.

Treatment: PublicationsFinancing prevention, testing and treatment of hepatitis in the context of Universal Health CoverageGuidelines for viral hepatitis planning and tracking progress towards eliminationImmunological basis for immunization: hepatitis AThe global prevalence of hepatitis A virus infection and susceptibility WHO position paper on hepatitis A vaccinesMore WHO publications More about hepatitisWHO's work on hepatitisGlobal Hepatitis Programme

Symptoms: Fluid buildup in the stomach area, called ascites., Swelling in the legs., Spiderlike blood vessels on the skin, called spider angiomas., Itchy skin., Fatigue., Confusion, drowsiness and slurred speech, called hepatic encephalopathy., Dark-colored urine., Bleeding easily., Weight loss.
Treatment: Pan-genotypic DAAs remain expensive in many high- and upper-middle-income countries. However, prices have dropped dramatically in many countries (primarily low-income and lower-middle-income countries) due to the introduction of generic versions of these medicines. The most widely used and low-cost pangenotypic DAA regimen is sofosbuvir and daclatasvir. In many low- and middle-income countries the curative treatment course is available for less than US$ 50.

Symptoms: Fluid buildup in the stomach area, called ascites., Swelling in the legs., Fatigue., Confusion, drowsiness and slurred speech, called hepatic encephalopathy., Bleeding easily., Weight loss.
Treatment: WHO recommends that all adults have access to and be offered HCV testing with linkage to prevention, care and treatment services.

Symptoms: Unusual tiredness and weakness, Yellowing of the skin and the whites of your eyes (jaundice), Clay- or gray-colored stool, Low-grade fever, Joint pain, Abdominal pain or discomfort, especially on the upper right side beneath your lower ribs, which is over your liver
Treatment: There is no specific antiviral treatment for hepatitis A. Instead, the management of hepatitis A focuses on supportive care to relieve symptoms and ensure adequate hydration and nutrition. Recovery from symptoms following infection may be slow and can take several weeks or months. It is important to avoid unnecessary medications that can adversely affect the liver, e.g. acetaminophen, paracetamol.

Symptoms: Confusion, drowsiness and slurred speech, called hepatic encephalopathy., Dark-colored urine., Bleeding easily., Weight loss.
Treatment: Access to HCV treatment is improving but remains limited. Of the 50 million people living with HCV infection globally in 2022, an estimated 36% people knew their diagnosis, and of those diagnosed with chronic HCV infection, around 20% (12.5 million) people had been treated with DAAs by the end of 2022.

Symptoms: Fluid buildup in the stomach area, called ascites., Swelling in the legs., Confusion, drowsiness and slurred speech, called hepatic encephalopathy., Dark-colored urine., Bleeding easily.

Treatment: There is no specific antiviral treatment for hepatitis A. Instead, the management of hepatitis A focuses on supportive care to relieve symptoms and ensure adequate hydration and nutrition. Recovery from symptoms following infection may be slow and can take several weeks or months. It is important to avoid unnecessary medications that can adversely affect the liver, e.g. acetaminophen, paracetamol.

Symptoms: Fluid buildup in the stomach area, called ascites., Swelling in the legs., Bruising easily., Spiderlike blood vessels on the skin, called spider angiomas., Yellowing of the skin, called jaundice. This might show up more in white people. Also, yellowing of the whites of the eyes in white, Black and brown people., Confusion, drowsiness and slurred speech, called hepatic encephalopathy., Dark-colored urine., Bleeding easily.
Treatment: Until recently, delivery of hepatitis C testing and treatment in many countries relied on specialist-led (usually by a hepatologist or gastroenterologist) care models in hospital settings to administer complex treatment. With the short-course oral, curative pangenotypic HCV DAA treatment regimens with few if any side-effects, minimal expertise and monitoring are now required. WHO recommends that testing, care and treatment for persons with chronic hepatitis C infection can be provided by trained non-specialist doctors and nurses, using simplified service delivery that includes decentralization, integration and task shifting. This can be done in primary care, harm reduction services and prisons which is more accessible and convenient for patients.

For World Hepatitis Day 2024, WHO focuses on the theme “It’s time for action” to illustrate the urgency of scaling up viral hepatitis prevention, testing and treatment to prevent liver diseases and cancer and achieve the 2030 hepatitis elimination target.

Symptoms: Swelling in the legs., Spiderlike blood vessels on the skin, called spider angiomas., Itchy skin., Fatigue., Confusion, drowsiness and slurred speech, called hepatic encephalopathy., Bleeding easily., Weight loss.
Treatment: WHO recommends therapy with pan-genotypic direct-acting antivirals (DAAs) for all adults, adolescents and children down to 3 years of age with chronic hepatitis C infection. The short-course oral, curative DAA treatment regimens has few if any side-effects. DAAs can cure most persons with HCV infection, and treatment duration is short (usually 12 to 24 weeks), depending on the absence or presence of cirrhosis. In 2022, WHO included new recommendations for treatment of adolescents and children using the same pangenotypic treatments used for adults.

Symptoms: Swelling in the legs., Spiderlike blood vessels on the skin, called spider angiomas., Fatigue., Confusion, drowsiness and slurred speech, called hepatic encephalopathy., Dark-colored urine., Bleeding easily., Weight loss.
Treatment: Early detection and treatment can prevent serious liver damage and improve long-term health.

The GHSS recommend shared and disease-specific country actions supported by
    actions by WHO and partners. They consider the epidemiological, technological,
    and contextual shifts of previous years, foster learnings across the disease
    areas, and create opportunities to leverage innovations and new knowledge for
    effective responses to the diseases. They call to scale up prevention, testing
    and treatment of viral hepatitis with a focus to reach populations and
    communities most affected and at risk for each disease, as well as addressing
    gaps and inequities. They promote synergies under a universal health coverage
    and primary health care framework and contribute to achieving the goals of the
    2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development.

Symptoms: Loss of appetite, Unusual tiredness and weakness, Yellowing of the skin and the whites of your eyes (jaundice), Clay- or gray-colored stool, Low-grade fever, Joint pain, Abdominal pain or discomfort, especially on the upper right side beneath your lower ribs, which is over your liver, Dark urine
Treatment: There is no specific antiviral treatment for hepatitis A. Instead, the management of hepatitis A focuses on supportive care to relieve symptoms and ensure adequate hydration and nutrition. Recovery from symptoms following infection may be slow and can take several weeks or months. It is important to avoid unnecessary medications that can adversely affect the liver, e.g. acetaminophen, paracetamol.

Symptoms: Loss of appetite, Yellowing of the skin and the whites of your eyes (jaundice), Clay- or gray-colored stool, Low-grade fever, Joint pain, Sudden nausea and vomiting and diarrhea, Abdominal pain or discomfort, especially on the upper right side beneath your lower ribs, which is over your liver
Treatment: WHO organizes annual World Hepatitis Day campaigns (as 1 of its 9 flagship annual health campaigns) to increase awareness and understanding of viral hepatitis. For World Hepatitis Day 2024, WHO focuses on the theme “It’s time for action” to illustrate the urgency of scaling up viral hepatitis prevention, testing and treatment to prevent liver diseases and cancer and achieve the 2030 hepatitis elimination target.

Treatment: WHO recommends that all adults have access to and be offered HCV testing with linkage to prevention, care and treatment services.

Treatment: Hospitalization is unnecessary in the absence of severe disease or acute liver failure. Therapy is aimed at maintaining comfort and adequate nutritional balance, including replacement of fluids that are lost from vomiting and diarrhoea.

Treatment: People with hepatitis C may also benefit from lifestyle changes, such as avoiding alcohol and maintaining a healthy weight. With proper treatment, many people can be cured from hepatitis C infection and live healthy lives.

Symptoms: Fluid buildup in the stomach area, called ascites., Bruising easily., Spiderlike blood vessels on the skin, called spider angiomas., Itchy skin., Fatigue., Yellowing of the skin, called jaundice. This might show up more in white people. Also, yellowing of the whites of the eyes in white, Black and brown people., Confusion, drowsiness and slurred speech, called hepatic encephalopathy., Bleeding easily.
Treatment: Early detection and treatment can prevent serious liver damage and improve long-term health.

Symptoms: Fluid buildup in the stomach area, called ascites., Swelling in the legs., Spiderlike blood vessels on the skin, called spider angiomas., Fatigue., Confusion, drowsiness and slurred speech, called hepatic encephalopathy., Bleeding easily., Not wanting to eat.
Treatment: Until recently, delivery of hepatitis C testing and treatment in many countries relied on specialist-led (usually by a hepatologist or gastroenterologist) care models in hospital settings to administer complex treatment. With the short-course oral, curative pangenotypic HCV DAA treatment regimens with few if any side-effects, minimal expertise and monitoring are now required. WHO recommends that testing, care and treatment for persons with chronic hepatitis C infection can be provided by trained non-specialist doctors and nurses, using simplified service delivery that includes decentralization, integration and task shifting. This can be done in primary care, harm reduction services and prisons which is more accessible and convenient for patients.

Symptoms: Swelling in the legs., Itchy skin., Confusion, drowsiness and slurred speech, called hepatic encephalopathy., Dark-colored urine., Bleeding easily., Not wanting to eat., Weight loss.
Treatment: After a person has been diagnosed with chronic HCV infection, an assessment should be conducted to determine the degree of liver damage (fibrosis and cirrhosis). This can be done by liver biopsy or through a variety of non-invasive tests. The degree of liver damage is used to guide treatment decisions and management of the disease.

Symptoms: Fluid buildup in the stomach area, called ascites., Bruising easily., Yellowing of the skin, called jaundice. This might show up more in white people. Also, yellowing of the whites of the eyes in white, Black and brown people., Confusion, drowsiness and slurred speech, called hepatic encephalopathy., Dark-colored urine., Bleeding easily., Not wanting to eat., Weight loss.
Treatment: Antiviral medications, including sofosbuvir and daclatasvir, are used to treat hepatitis C. Some people's immune system can fight the infection on their own and new infections do not always need treatment. Treatment is always needed for chronic hepatitis C.
